content.description: A steep, tricky start from a somewhat loose detached flake leads to tenuous lay backing up a finger crack to a crux undercling move to a fun slab finish.
content.protection: Anchor: Nut or small cam and a bolt.
content.location: Start on the Left side of the rock from a detached flake (careful!)  to reach the crack.

content.description: The hardest moves are at the start leading to balance moves up the face, angle left to join Humdinger at its crux undercling.
content.protection: Anchor: Nut or small cam and bolt
content.location: Start on the right side of the rock, continue up the steep face to join Humdinger near the top.

content.description:
Out with the fam for a momorial day weekend camping trip and decided to do some bouldering in the area. This is my first project I have put up on here. Hope ya'll like it! This problem is a nice, mostly slopey traverse. The crux is the starting move, moving from the large slopey hold to the smaller sloper-crimp. Fairly easy climb, good for v2 to v3

gym

climbers. In the picture the the green mark is the starting hold, the yellow is the other hand holds, and the red are the foot holds.
content.protection: Crash pad is a good option but isn't need since you are only like a foot off the ground during the side step (traverse) part of the climb before topping out.
content.location: In Fern Basin campground. A large boulder with a big crack in, it's hard to miss. It is on the left of campsite number 4 (if you are facing the mountain)

content.description: Start on Humdinger then move left into a series of underclings along the prow of the steep arete until you gain a finger crack.  Climb along the arching crack until it is possible to exit the crack and continue of the rounded arete.  This climb has it all!
content.location: Obvious Steep arete at the left corner of the rock
